segments.text: Altsuarez by Linda Mendez from December 4th, 1988 at my home in Houston concerning the Vietnam War.
In the interest of accumulating knowledge about the war, I am going to donate this tape to the Texas A&M Oral History Collection in the University Archives.
Is this all right with you?
The answer was yes.
What is your date and place of birth?
He was born on February 25th, 1950.
born here in Houston, Texas.
What type of education did you have prior to going into Vietnam?
Prior to going to Vietnam, a high school diploma and one year at San Jacinto Junior College.
How and why did you join the military?
Well, I joined the military for basically two reasons.
Number one, I wasn't doing too well in school.
I didn't maintain a B average, which essentially at that particular time meant that you were more prone to getting drafted, and I felt that my time would be coming up soon.
Basically, I felt like a change was needed, and so I made the attempt to
at least talk with the enlisted people with the United States Air Force.
They, in turn, were very much interested.

But luckily, for an unknown reason, a cousin of mine who had just returned from Vietnam happened to talk with me about that subject and really gave me a strong impression that maybe two years of induction would be more beneficial to me.
at which point then I did go directly to the Selective Service and then request for induction as a draftee, that they would send me and immediately induct me.
I don't regret doing that, it's just that I felt somewhere along the line that I really needed to find my future and myself, and I so chose to do that.
Dealing with the Selective Service, did you notice any kind of,
While you being there, did you notice any prejudices towards other people?
Like, for instance, didn't they had to judge you on whether or not they chose people to go to Vietnam?
Did you notice any kind of?
Well, during the induction period, one thing I did notice, you didn't find too many upper class individuals.
were very few college students.
You could tell simply by the way that they talked that they were more educated than the ones that were around me.
Very many blacks, very many of the people like me, 18 and 19 year olds were there.
And I really didn't see anybody that to me looked outstanding as far as looking on the upper echelons of society.
This was strictly
an induction of the lower spectrum of society, at least that's from my point of view.
Where were you stationed during your tour of duty and what was your job?
Are you referring to the processes of what I went through?
Upon the induction date that evening, I took a long bus ride to Fort Polk, Louisiana, to which I began my boot training.
and I stayed eight weeks there before going on to advance individual training at Fort Sam Houston in San Antonio.
There I stayed a total of ten weeks before actually getting a permanent assigned duty at Fort Leonard Wood Army General Hospital in Leonard Wood, Missouri.
Is all this
Like, is this all, when you first joined, is this all you did right before you went into Vietnam?
I mean, is this like, this would be your military career before Vietnam?
Right, prior to going, right.
Okay.
And when you went, when you finally got to Vietnam, did you feel that the training that you had was going to be sufficient, or did you have any idea what was going to be expected of you?
Well, I was, yeah, I was fortunate.
in the sense that when I was assigned my permanent duty at Leonard Wood Army General Hospital, I was assigned specifically to the emergency room.
That in itself brought on a new change in my attitudes toward life.
I began to see so much.
It's really strange, you know, from a kid that used to wake up and play baseball from 8 o'clock in the morning at the local park with all the rest of the gang

until about 9.30 at night, you know, that was the bulk of my summer activities a lot, just playing ball and enjoying being with my local friends, to having to work in an emergency room where little kids come in, not being able to breathe, accident cases, just a whole range of things that occur inside an emergency room of a major hospital.
in a major area in Leonardwood.
It's actually in between Rolla, Missouri and Springfield, Missouri, in a stretch of road, probably one of the most dangerous of all the country.
The hills of the Ozark Mountains there caused a lot of fatalities.
And having been stationed there, I did a lot of ambulance runs.
I did a lot of work there on trauma cases.
And that in itself gave me a much more controlling factor on my part of knowing that
I could, if engaged in combat, be able to or feel confident enough that I could be able to conduct myself and work and potentially save lives.
Basically, I felt very strong that if it wasn't for that, I wouldn't have felt that I was capable of being able to control myself in Vietnam.
Okay.
Before you went to Vietnam, whatever you visualized of it being like, or what did you visualize Vietnam being like?
Prior to going?
Well, I was like most other Americans.
Six o'clock news, that's all you saw.
Luckily, I didn't have any cousins that were there or somebody close.
I had friends that I went to school with, one in particular that passed away, that I found out had died in Vietnam.
It was really strange to visually think about him, because a year had passed by before I realized that something had happened to him.
I don't really know how many of my fellow students went to Vietnam.
I really haven't just tried to even inquire.
But just basically, like most Americans, we didn't really know what was going on.
And that was part of my curiosity about wanting to go there, too.

And as during the time period that things were beginning to happen at Leonardwood, in the sense of getting bored, getting into trouble in the sense of getting into trouble and the fact that in one particular incident I yelled at Lieutenant Colonel and could have probably gotten a court martial except that the surgeon

general of the hospital backed me up and saying that I was corrected when I was doing and that made me feel good but at the same time I felt that it was just coming to a boiling point and just being someplace and doing the emergency work there working 14 sometimes 16 hours a day and all that just came into play the stress there came into play and when I get rather I received orders to go to Germany but then I went back to personnel and told them hey
No, that's not what I really want.
I cannot, I do not feel like I want to find another Leonard Wood in Missouri, you know, in Germany.

So then I suggested that Vietnam would probably be the best place for me to go and I felt that I acquired enough knowledge or at least felt strong enough that I could do my job there or I could do a job there.
But I didn't know much about Vietnam other than from what I'd heard from the fellow workers and
I didn't feel like it would be that much different, really.
So you didn't feel like there was a difference between, say, the land itself?
You had just no idea what it was like?
Well, here again, you're right.
I have no idea what the jungle is like or what the different areas are like.
But if it was going to be jungle, I remember the days when my dad would talk to me about fighting in the islands, the island hopping that he did.
in World War II in the Pacific, and I felt like that was enough for me.
I think I could do just as well.
Did you think that Vietnam was going to be anything like the previous wars, like World War II?
Oh, no.
That was something that, in talking with many returning Vietnam individuals at the military base in Leonardwood, that it wasn't like that.
But at the same time, I had to see it.
Having been in Missouri long enough, I learned to acquire that seeing and believing is something you need to do.
Show me.
Did you know or understand the reason that the United States was in Vietnam?
At that particular time, no.
Did you have any kind of, what was your...
I didn't really, to me, at that particular time period, I was more concerned with developing my own life than the real issue.
It took many years later before I began to understand and to acquire enough knowledge as to why the domino theory was so strong and why we were there, basically.
Going in, did you believe anything about the domino theory?
That didn't really interest me too much.
I was among so many people my age, so many people that were like me in the era, that time period.
the real military strategy just didn't really affect anybody.
We were there simply because we were there, either because we wanted to be there or because we just accepted the orders.
We didn't rebel.
We were just there, you know, and the job that needed to be done, we felt like, well, we're here, so we'll just go ahead and get it done.
What about the Vietnamese people?
Did you have any idea, anything about their culture?
No, no.
I had no idea what
what these people were like.
They, to me, were peasants in the sense of the country that they lived in.
They were farmers.
But as far as knowing them or knowing what was to be expected, I really didn't.
The only indoctrination we got was about an hour of Vietnamese culture, which didn't really say anything.
Technically, we were not really, and I don't think there was anybody in the military that was really trained for the type of conditions we were going to go into and the reasons for why we were there.
We just had to accept the orders.
Okay.
About the tour of duty, how did you feel about the tour of duty just being one year?
Did you think that that hurt or that helped, the fact that you were only there for a year and then gone?
Well, in my particular case, wanting to be drafted and knowing the two-year induction, I knew that sooner or later it was time to go home.
The one-year period, as far as the issue is concerned, I never really dealt with that until years later when I began to really think about all that had happened.
One year is sufficient.
But at the same time, under the conditions that we saw and under the conditions that existed there,
Two days was too long.
But you knew that 365 days your tour was over.
And actually I went there at a time period that I would be there less than a year anyway.
So in that respect I knew sooner or later the day would come when the oilers would come down and I'd be ready to make my way back to Houston.
Okay.
How did
your unit, you and your unit, try and fight the war itself, like the operations?
Well, to begin with, the 2nd of the 7th, which is the 2nd Battalion 7th Cavalry Regiment, which is part of the 1st Cav Air Mobile Unit, we were infantrymen.
We were walking through jungles, triple canopy, a lot of vegetation.
four trails in search of the NVA and the VC militarily.
The areas that we worked in were combatant areas that meant anybody there was free game.
Didn't matter if it was a child, didn't matter if it was a grandmother, it didn't matter.
They had no business being there.
They were told not to be there.
Our operations were then search and destroy.
It's a hard feeling, but at the same time, it's one of those that
was a part of the operation.
That's what you're trained for.
Were there any problems with orders from the commanders to the soldiers themselves about the soldiers not wanting to go along with what was being said?
We had a lot of disputes.
In fact, I happened to be there at the time period that the refusals of walking trails became very much an important issue among the men.
We knew we were there for less than a year.
We weren't concerned about becoming generals.
We were concerned about doing something that was right.
It was surprising that most of the people that I worked with, the people that I was with, were more intelligent than I really thought.
They were like me, a year of college now, or two years of college.
Some of them did it simply because they found themselves caught in a dilemma of finances or caught in a dilemma of going to jail or going to war.
this particular case, I had many people that were smarter than me, you know, and I believe we talked to each other in the different parts of the country that we were with.
And the most important thing we wanted to do was come home.
So when it comes to walking a trail and knowing that you could be ambushed, you could be a sitting duck, no.
We rebelled.
I was there
Just about the time period that the news media was capturing this rebellious act.
In fact, our company was one of the ones, our battalion was one of the ones interviewed, and pictures being sent back about military morale going down.
How did they deal with that?
How did the commanders deal with it?
Well, as I say, the media took hold of that, and when the politicians brought it back,

the message was then filtered back, I guess, you know, this is my personal point of view, was filtered back into saying that, you know, start, stop your military young lieutenants from forcing the issue and start listening to the men a little bit more because they actually, now, you know, now that the war is dying out and pacification has taken, has taken in place that we really don't need bad publicity for the war.
And, uh,

I'm sure that in Washington they felt very strongly that we needed to pick up the morale and we needed the American people behind us, backing us, because the war was coming to a close, but at the same time you didn't want any hard feelings.
We eventually learned that many of our young lieutenants found themselves not being able to be heard when they spoke.
And I think it finally came to a point after several deaths that the message got out that we meant business.
We want to come home alive and not in a box or in a bag.
Did any of that ever result in fragging of the officers in the cells that you know of?
Actually, and specifically, there was a case, and I never really dealt with trying to find out whether
This was the actual court martial.
The day that I went into the field, the evening that I sat in a fire base, beginning to see the men that I'd be working with, there was a young second lieutenant who was going home.
He was actually getting ready to be processed out, start his process out the next day.
And he was well liked by many of them.
the medics that were with me by many of the people that he worked with.
He had learned to work with his men.
And during the era that we went into Cambodia, which I missed, but that he was there, they had learned to like each other.
And he was well liked.
Anyway, that particular night, we had an opportunity to talk.
Of course, I didn't really know him because I was new.
very green into the country, and this particular individual.
I spoke just very briefly.
But he seemed like a good person.
He was just a very strong attitude, very well-educated.
And I felt like, well, he was there.
It was time for him to go home, and he did his duty.
But we went out on the field for several days, and when we came back,
the word came out to me that he was involved in an incident in which he was killed.
And I couldn't believe that because it just seemed that this guy looked, you know, hey, he's going home.
He was real happy.
And that's when everything started coming back to me as far as what this whole world was all about.
Prior to that particular night, I was in Phuc Vinh, the night that I met him.
I was in ,, which was the headquarters division.
And I never really realized just how much hatred there was in this world.
But we had plenty of Black Panther or Malcolm X people, I guess.
I don't really know.
It's just a lot of Black sentiment there.
Many of the Blacks that were there felt like the whole world was against them.
And they pretty well protect themselves.
I remember a couple of them just constantly talking about,
and using the language that they use, you know, about the whites and all this and that.
So I realized there was a lot of bigotry and racial indifferences there.

I didn't realize how drastic it became, but apparently the more, the closer you are to the weapons as they were there, it became real easy for instances to occur, especially the utter hatred that was there.
And I, you know, and hearing...
And like I said, I really, this is something that just happened to happen.
But in overhearing some of the things that were said, it just, I played it down.
I didn't, you know, I was new there, so I really didn't know what to expect.
But it was just funny that here was a land that we were fighting, you know, an enemy, the NVA and the VC.
At the same time, our worst enemy was ourselves.
And in this particular case, when I found out that this fragging had occurred, the intention was to kill the first sergeant.
The first sergeant wasn't even in the building.
The frag supposedly rolled underneath the bunk in which the young dude, the first lieutenant, was sitting in.
And apparently, he never knew what happened.
But it was really surprising that years later, I read about it.
I just happened to be looking at the paper, and I happened to see a

first court martial dealing with the fragging incidents and it happened to be of a unit close to mine and I just put two and two together and said most likely in the back of my mind this is actually the situation that I knew of and although it was just one of those things that do occur it's one of those that begin to
make you feel that, you know, why am I here?
Because even if I, even if we win this war, I'm still going to, I'm still going to, I'll go back home to find that there's another war there.
You know, and it really, it's really degrading, especially for morale purposes.
You know, why are we there?
Why are we there?
Our real problems are really at home.
And so in this case, this became really the first major incident that I had that occurred to me.
And
and specifically where fragging occurs.
Okay, what about the problems with drugs?
Did that have any negative effect on the fighting itself?
Or did it have any effect at all?
Well, drugs per se were more prevalent back in the installations.
Out in the field, you were crazy if you lit up a joint because they gave you away.

I remember one incident where one of the new guys, and this was several months after I'd been out in the field, one of the new guys came in, it was a black dude, he came in and he just went off to himself, just about 20 feet away from everybody, and he lit up a joint.
He very quickly put that joint away when several of our rifles were pointed right at his head and said, you better not ever do that again.
And then he all of a sudden felt like, you know,
Well, this is the way I interpreted the war to be like.
Well, I know he was black, and I know everybody called him the words we often hear, you dumb nigger, you know, but it's essentially the same thing.
He learned very quickly that this isn't the place for this, you know, and he never did it again, but he always remembered that if they didn't kill him, we would, you know.
Because we want to go home.
That was the main thesis, is to count your days and essentially to come home.
Were there any particular operations that were either successes, great successes, or just tremendous failures that you would like to talk about?
Well, when you're out in the field, every day is an operation.
Because every moment could be a last moment.
We had several cases and several incidences that occurred with units that I was with, but none of them really stood out.
It seemed like every day was just one of those days that, you know, really every day was a day to remember.
There are some that stand out a little bit more, and I don't really know whether the successes are now.
Apparently they did, because we ended up getting steaks and ice cream, and that's one of the rarities you find in the war.
How did they measure the...
the progress y'all were making?
Well, actually we weren't, you know, we weren't really dealing with a measurement.

I, if you're referring to kill count and the war was coming to a more controlling factor, we were giving more of the South Vietnamese more of the areas where it was really dangerous or we felt it was dangerous.
I don't know, it was hard for me to judge that because
It seemed like every time we had an operation or we had to go out in the field, we were going out in the field with potentially 200 to 300 feet seated where to be located.
Because that was an area where the sensor devices and the night airplanes had noticed a lot of movement.
So every day was an operation in itself.
We stood very firm, very close, and ties communications to make sure that if we did run into a problem that we would get the backing.
One particular incident.
February the 11th, I believe it was February the 11th.
I'm almost positive that day always stands out in my mind.

We were, our operations generally kept the platoons no more than a mile apart in the areas that we were sweeping to look for these bunkers and these battalion strength personnel that we were looking for.
And there's one particular incident
We were standing around and all of a sudden the word came out that one of the platoons had hit contact.
And it seemed like all of a sudden everybody became supermen because we were all doing things that we generally don't do, and that is functioning together.
We were always griping with each other, you know, and telling each other, you stupid, crazy person or whatever.
But, you know, you ain't going home and your girlfriend's out with some other guy.
We were always criticizing each other.
In this particular case, all of a sudden, we all snapped and said, hey, you know, this other platoon is in trouble.
We got the word through the company commander to converge.
Immediately, we all began to get our stuff together, and we started running.
And we ran down trails that we probably would never want to do, but the objective was to hurry up and get to the platoon that was hit and provide the perimeter support.
secure the perimeter in order to get the people that were hurt out of there.
I ran like I'd never run before.
I guess I was glad that I was so physically fit.
And before I knew it, you know, through the jungle, jumping over the dead logs, and I have no idea if I stepped on a boa constrictor or not, but I think I did.
Something was slippery when I stepped on one.
We made our engagement.
And immediately upon arriving, I could see and I could hear the moans and the groans and the smell of powder.
And there was still contact.
We were still fighting.
Some of the guys up in front were fighting.
One of the soldiers was hit really bad, and his stomach was torn apart.
He was screaming and hollering.
damn it, he didn't want to die here.
This wasn't the way it was supposed to be.
We had two of the medics, the headquarters medics, was already there.
And one of the other platoons was arriving very quickly.
We were all converging pretty close.
We weren't really that far.
A mile apart is not really that far, but yet in a jungle it seems like 100 miles.
Anyway, we very quickly

encountered the immediate spot where the entanglement occurred, and then were given the directions of where the fighting was, and it wasn't just, you know, listed 50 feet further up, but he couldn't see it because of the thickness of the jungle.
I don't know what was in the back of my mind.
Not that I didn't care.
I just thought that it was something I needed to do, and I just immediately took two of the guys, went straight on up front,
where there was another person that was hit.
And I didn't really realize it, because everything was happening so fast, that this other person that was hit had some fragments in his lung.
And another one had something had gotten into his eye.
He wasn't really sure if it was a fragment or he'd cut it.
Anyway, I began to do my duties with them.
I never really realized that less than 20 feet away there was a VC that was shooting in the opposite direction.

And it just so happened that one of the guys that was with me happened to see him, it was just by accident, because there was so much noise going on and so much bombing going on, people throwing frags and everything, that he happened to see him and so he terminated him.
At that particular time, you did things, and you just didn't, you functioned.
This is what you were trained for.
You don't have time to be sentimental or thinking.
You just did it.

Well, it was really just one of those operations where, I guess, if it was successful, it was the fact that we all played an important part in securing the area as well as being able to get the area to where we could get a helicopter to come in there and take the men that were hurt.
It seemed like just a few days later when we were able to get into a nice, clear area of secureness that the hired officers came by and then awarded medals to the bravery.
I guess that's where I got my first one.
I'm positive.
So many things happen so much, you just accept them and it's just like I say, every day is a different day.
And in respect, I believe that there's no doubts about it.
That's why I received my first Bronze Star with Valor.
The other one deals with another incident, which I don't wish to really talk about.
But as far as successes, that was just one incident.
There were so many, and I guess that one stands out because I can still hear them yelling sometimes from time to time.
that, damn, I don't want to go home, but I don't want to go home in a bag.
Essentially, he died.
We had a few.
We had a few of them with us.
Basically, they were scouts.
And a scout is just one who is a little more familiar with the terrain than we are.
Of course, we were already familiar with it had we been there for a while.
In the event we encountered contact, if there was an opportunity to be able to discuss with these people why they were out there or if they were VC, he'd have an opportunity to talk with them.
The ones that worked with us just a few times, we really didn't have too many of them, but the one that worked with us essentially went to another platoon.
I understand, or I heard later on that
that he accidentally blew himself up when he was trying to throw a grenade in an encounter.
And that's just about the last one I remember.
There were a few, but not that many.
And we essentially were more into lacking a being to ourselves.
It was just a trust problem.
We didn't really, a lot of us didn't trust anybody that was from Vietnam.
is that home feeling, you wanted to go home.
You didn't want to get, you didn't want to find yourself totally trusting someone that could eventually, in this particular war, may eventually be the enemy.
You couldn't tell the difference.
Did you have a hard time telling the enemy from, like, say, the Vietnamese and the NVA and the VC?
Vietnam in itself, say, they
The French Vietnamese, of course, characteristically are different from the Chinese Vietnamese.
And the Chinese are definitely distinctive between them.
I mean, we ran into one that was at least 6'2".
He was just, I guess, an advisor for the NBA.
But essentially, this is what we were looking for.
We were looking for the people that were hard cadre, hardcore, because they were the ones that we felt
would intermingle with VC and organize and then provide the real confrontations that were prevalent throughout the country at all times.
And in this particular case, during my tour of duty, we were constantly bumping into VC and NVA, which you really couldn't distinguish many of them.
Because when they'd come into the country, essentially, they couldn't wear the type of uniforms or the type of clothing that they
war in the north, simply to give them away, so that's why we couldn't really tell.
DC people basically looked all the same to the southern Vietnamese people.
That's why you really didn't trust anyone there.
You made that number one priority.
Being in Vietnam, seeing how your unit was fighting the war, what y'all were doing, did you at the time think that you were winning the war, or did you have any idea?
We didn't care.
We were there, and we knew, and we wanted to come home.
We didn't care.
We cared about securing ourselves, and we cared about wanting to go home, but as far as winning the war, we already knew it was lost.
I don't think there are too many GIs that fought in the jungle that really felt that the war was a winning war.
We were there for police action only, and that as long as the politicians back home

did not give us the full strength and power that we needed, and all of the problems that were involved in there, such as having to have South Vietnamese approval before you could bomb the country, and having to spend nights in unsecured areas.
I can remember one night we stayed awake all night long because we wanted arterial support.
We couldn't get it because of the allocations.
They had already let go of all the bombs that they could get rid of that day.
So we had to wait till morning.
That seems very stupid to me.
Even the emergency allocations were gone.
And all that amounted to is that we were playing a game of numbers, and that's why I guess essentially most of us just got turned off.
What do you think could have done to...
as far as the military was concerned, to try to win it?
At that particular time, I don't think anybody knew.
I guess that's why I met Westmoreland and got out of it.
I don't really know.
When you think about it, we weren't fighting a conventional war, which we were trained for.
That's what we went to do training for, conventional warfare.
Those are the ones that were able to go to advance military training in infantry, continued on with the conventional war.
I mean, that's large units, big firepower, utilization of men, and essentially you were plunging into something.
We were scattered, and we found ourselves like policemen on the streets in Houston, you know.
If an incident occurs, well, they all converge together, and that's essentially what we did.
We did a policing action.
This war of attrition, actually, was that in itself.
A little fighting here, a little fighting there, just something to keep nibbling away.
There were really no major offenses like the offense of 1968 in the tent.
We looked forward to one in 1971, but it didn't materialize, I guess,
I guess General Gieff didn't want to lose any more men than he had lost in previous engagements, General Gieff being the main military mind of the NVA.
So I don't know really what could have been done other than giving us the full strength of going in there and going all forth.
We probably should have gone into Hanoi.
I don't know if that would have made much difference either.
Sometimes, you know, you think about it, it just would have been a cost of more lives on our part.
But at the same time, with the politicalness that was going on and the atmosphere, you know, of just wait and see, that I don't really feel that at any time we were going to win the war.
And I don't think anybody really felt that there was really a want and desire to win a war or win.
Right.
There's just too much at stake, too much cost, too much money, too many lives.
So the police action seemed to be the best approach.
Did you witness any pacification at all while you were in Vietnam?
Yes.
It's interesting with the time period that I was in the field.
I was in combatant areas.
But the 1st Cav, being the type of unit that it was and winning so many of the awards that it did,
the time was coming for the divisions to come home.
And out of the five divisions, four of them came home.
We had a big stand-down.
Secretary of State Dean Rusk was present, and all the generals and South Vietnamese president, I believe.
I don't know why.
I don't really remember who he was.
But we had a huge, huge gathering of all of them, all of the men in a great march.
It was just a huge thing.
on the field by Ben Wyer base.
And right afterwards, then everybody got reassigned.
Those that were coming home could come home.
Many got early outs to come home.
But I was too new into the country.
I didn't have the time period.
And I still had time before my two years were up that I got reassigned.
My reassignment went to the 229th Helicopter Assault Battalion, which was basically the helicopter unit servicing the 1st Cav for the division that was still there.
And so then my tour of duty became more of working there in Benoit, at which time then we did begin to, I began to see more of the pacification programs
helping the citizens.
And so I took part in several of them in the sense of going down into the towns and going into Saigon and going into the orphanages and working with the people.
We were, at the same time, giving more and more of the duty of combat to the South Vietnamese at that time.
And so we began to see more and more of the South Vietnamese soldiers.
which we didn't see before, or at least I didn't.
I saw the change coming on, and it was funny how they... We knew that essentially we were going to give up our barracks to the South Vietnamese, and so we started cleaning them up.
That's probably direct as you can be.
You're cleaning up your barracks, you're planting flowers around your bunks, you're raking the area, you're...
Even the latrines were cleaned a little bit more.
And now all that had to do with was, you know, as far as we were concerned, is eventually we were going to go home and the South Vietnamese were going to take over the base.
And essentially that's what happened anyway after the last of the men, I think, I believe in 72, started coming home.
What about, like you said, you were in the jungle.
Was the weather or the climate itself a hazard being there?
Well, you know, when you freeze to death at 90 degrees, the weather has an effect on you.
When you hike the jungle, of course, there's a lot of moisture in the jungle, and you're sweating all the time.
You get into a clearing spot where the sun can beat on you, and there you are.
And basically every three to seven days you'd get,
a new pair of clothes, just clean clothes, it's all a matter of two.
The weather beats on you.
It's unfortunate that 3.30 to 5.30 every evening during the monsoon rain season, the rains would come.
Temperatures would drop to 80, 90 degrees and you'd freeze.
You'd be freezing because you were used to the 110 degrees.

120 degrees and the humidity is no different you know and it's effect than windshield factor you know I mean just you your body just can't you know it doesn't take it and so we found ourselves just uh from time to time just really wishing that we were out of there you know when you're soaking wet the rest of the night and then you got to fight leeches in the evening because they might get in they might crawl up up to you especially if you crawled if you've gone through a little river or
a little creek, and the way the terrain is, it's just a jungle, and a jungle, it's hard to describe.
There's just nothing but leaves and leaves, more leaves, and snakes and all other little insects that you just don't want to think about anymore, but it did have an effect.
What about the anti-war demonstrators?
How did you feel about those, seeing how you were there fighting and they didn't want to go?
Well, let's start from the beginning first.
You know, I didn't go.
You know, the Chicago scene had already occurred in 68.
I think with the election, you know, Richard Nixon had won presidency.
There was a lot going on, but it wasn't close to me because I was graduating from high school then.
You know, I was thinking about a future and not, you know, necessarily about a war.
As I said, I really didn't
know any more about the war than what I saw on 6 o'clock news.
But at the same time, anti-war demonstrations of that period didn't really affect me.
Even while over there in the jungle, the military was very good about not bringing up any of that subject.
And so you just generally didn't hear it, except from the letters, the letters from coming back home from people who would talk about
Did you hear about Kent State?
Or whatever the case was.
So anti-war demonstrating really didn't mean much to me until I came back home at that point.

Then I realized that this continuance of this war that meant nothing to the people that I was with, then I started beginning to voice my opinion against it, which I took part in the march here in Houston where we walked from downtown on to
onto the Herman Park and had our little rally.
But as far as anti-war demonstrations at that particular time period, I didn't really deal with it because it didn't have any psychological barrier with me.
Right.
But now that afterwards, and having gone back and starting to think about it, now I can remember when in boot training, the National Guards, the reservists,
We had plenty of them from New Jersey that were with us.
They'd always be laughing about, oh, are you going to Vietnam?
I'm going to go back home.
How did you know about that?
Well, I didn't really care about them, so I didn't listen to them.
But at the same time, I knew that my tour duty probably would amount to going there.
And as far as they were concerned, it wasn't anything that they had to worry about.
You know, I think I mentioned once that, you know, they do activate National Guard units every once in a while.
I think they did in Ohio once, you know.
But it was just a tactic, you know, just something to get back at them.
But generally I knew that there were so many who did evade the draft and evade service in Vietnam that, you know, I became one of the few that...
You know, it was always talked about in the sense that you went over, you're going over there, you went over there, you know.
I got all the negative feedback, which had some psychological bearing for a little while.
But as the years have gone by, you know, I feel totally different, you know.
I did my part.
I stood, you know, I stood out.
I can't say the same for them.
Do you have any negative feelings towards those who evaded the draft or...
Yeah, well, you look at a vice president now that did it.
I don't have any sentiment for him, really.
I could care less that he is vice president.
I hope to hell George Bush doesn't walk away from the presidency because I can't imagine somebody like that leading our country.
